Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; well detailed, though quite rubbed, back with some modelling for head and clypeus, simple incised divisions in single line for prothorax and elytra, and triangular winglets on either side; underside decorated with a winged human-headed sphinx, walking to right, bearing a long beard; a few incised details within its body; pierced lengthwise; glaze lost; pale yellow paste; very eroded surface.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Musée du Louvre. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Scarabs with a winged sphinx motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 28-30, see especially 29 for this piece though the wings are omitted on the drawing). Gorton assigned this scarab to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII A, subtype A91-107, see especially A92 for this piece). The drawing of the motif is, however, more refined than usual and does not seem to be stamped, but rather carved with fine incisions. Its size and technique recall more her type XXXIV A (Gorton 1996, 121-123). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 29) (same type)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.021) (phase 3)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 97, type XXVIII A92)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musée du Louvre, Paris
